group_1.textRight: ...Huff, huff...
There are bugs again...@I wonder why they gather so much.
...Alright, here it is.
It has become clean.
This blue flower...@Do you remember it, Dolma...?

group_1.textLeft: You are working hard.

group_1.textRight: ...Not really...I'm just doing it because@I was told to.

group_1.textLeft: However, these flowers were neglected,@and they've become so beautiful...
...It's thanks to you.

group_1.textRight: Hah... I understand your intentions.
Through taking care of the flowers, you want to@spark my interest in the nunnery
and make me work hard for the sake of@everyone here...
...Isn't that right?

group_1.textLeft: You're incredibly level-headed.
However, that's not it.
I just want you to come to like the nunnery...@That's all.

group_1.textRight: I do like everything except the training.

group_1.textLeft: Are you still not used to it?

group_1.textRight: It's not that I'm not used to it...@I just don't quite understand it, you know?

group_1.textLeft: You don't understand?

group_1.textRight: No, I don't.@I don't understand the hatred.

group_1.textLeft: Is that...because you want to save the@Mongolian soldiers too?

group_1.textRight: No, it's not something as noble as that.@I mean...
...It just feels pointless.
Oh, I'm not looking down on anyone or getting@frustrated, it's not about that.
I just think we could spend our days more brightly@and happily instead of doing such pointless things...
If we did that, wouldn't everyone be happy...?
Wouldn't that be better?

group_1.textLeft: ...Because you think we can't win against the@Mongolian Army anyway?

group_1.textRight: Yes.

group_1.textLeft: ...Your hometown was destroyed by the@Mongolian Army, right?
And even then, you don't feel hatred?

group_1.textRight: What good would it do to hate them?
...I'm just following the teachings and living@peacefully without crying or getting angry.
Isn't that good enough?

group_1.textLeft: ...However, that won't protect anything.
We don't know much about the Rakshasi.
They possess extraordinary powers,@they exorcise demons...
But we don't know why they can do such things.
The only thing we know is that with that power,@they can protect a lot.
You must have something you want to@protect too, right...?

group_1.textRight: Something I want to protect...
I'm sorry, Dolma. I'm late...

group_1.textLeft: Ugh...

group_1.textRight: Dolma...

group_1.narration: Dolma used to be scared of the night@and often cried.
...Because the Mongolian Army had@attacked us at night...
When Dolma noticed me,@she looked a little embarrassed.
I smiled a little and reached out my hand,@as if I hadn't seen anything.

group_1.textRight: It's okay, I am here.

group_1.textLeft: Yeah...

group_1.textRight: Should we go to bed?@It's already time to sleep.

group_1.textLeft: ...Could you stop using that way of speaking?@Talk like you used to, back in the day.

group_1.textRight: I've already forgotten what that way of@speaking was like.

group_1.textLeft: Before they called you a savior in your hometown...
you didn't speak so politely.
...Talk like you used to back then.

group_1.textRight: That's why... I've already forgotten.
Besides, Dolma, your way of speaking@has changed too.

group_1.textLeft: That's...because I wanted to be more@equal with you...

group_1.textRight: Anyway, everything changes and shifts over time.
You can't return things to how they used to be...

group_1.narration: But there's one thing that hasn't changed for me...@I want to protect you, Dolma.
If things go on like this, you might become a Rakshasi,@and tragedy might await...
What should I do?@Should I become a Rakshasi in place of Dolma?
Should I carry the hopes of the people once again and@fight against the Mongolian Army...?

group_1.textCenter: ...Should I become a Rakshasi,@the hope of everyone...?
But I don't really understand everyone's feelings.
